content: # Water Quality Diagnosis and Treatment Guide

This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for identifying water quality issues in heating systems, including chemical inhibitor testing, magnetite buildup detection, corrosion patterns, and water hardness effects.
- **Oxygen Corrosion**: Results in red/brown iron oxide
- **Microbial Corrosion**: Bacterial activity causing metal degradation
- **Acid Attack**: Low pH causing metal dissolution
- **Algae Growth**: In systems with light exposure
- **Incorrect pH Levels**: Too high or too low
- **Dissolved Gas Issues**: Excessive oxygen, nitrogen, hydrogen
- Forms a sludge that settles in low flow areas
- Can become suspended during system operation
- Particle size varies from microscopic to visible
- Mixed metal systems without proper inhibition
- Frequent system draining allowing oxygen ingress
- Low system pressure causing air intake
- Draw samples from multiple system points
- Use clear container against white background
- Allow sample to settle and observe
- Look for black particles that respond to magnet
- Examine pump impeller for black deposits
- Look for settled material in low points
- Check strainers and filters for black residue
- Note cold spots at radiator bottoms
- Check for reduced flow in specific circuits
- Test flow rates across system sections
- Use external magnets on pipes to detect attraction
- Check strength of attraction at different points
- Note pattern of buildup at low points
- Test radiators externally with strong magnets
- Install magnetic filter if not present
- Measures water clarity in NTU (Nephelometric Turbidity Units)
- Specialized equipment to quantify magnetic content
- Identifies partial blockages in heat emitters
- pH buffers to maintain optimal range
- Molybdate test kits for molybdate-based inhibitors
- Colorimetric test strips for specific formulations
- Water sample clarity and color analysis
- Tracking of pH stability over time
- Check system metallurgy against inhibitor type
- Verify approved use with special components (aluminum)
- Test for adverse reactions with existing treatment
- Review system history for previous treatments
- Symptoms: Test shows below recommended level, early corrosion signs
- Cause: Insufficient dosing, dilution from leaks, adsorption
* Calculate correct dose for system volume
* Check for and fix minor leaks
- Cause: High temperature degradation, microbial action, incompatibility
* Drain and refill if severely degraded
* Add biocide if microbial activity suspected
- Symptoms: Specific corrosion of certain metals
- Cause: Inhibitor not suitable for system metallurgy
* Consider specific aluminum protection for combi boilers
* Flush system before changing inhibitor types
- F&E tank addition for open systems
- Inline dosing units for large systems
- **Common Locations**: Air collection points, near feed points
- **Indicators**: Recurring air in system, pressure drops
- **Appearance**: White deposits near dissimilar metal joints
- **Indicators**: Accelerated corrosion of less noble metal
- **Testing**: Visual inspection, pH near affected areas, metallurgical analysis
- **Common Locations**: Pipe bends, restrictions, valve entries
- **Indicators**: Premature thinning in high flow areas
- **Appearance**: Small, deep holes in metal surfaces
- Document location and appearance of corrosion
- Look for patterns across multiple points
- Check maintenance records for recurring issues
- Test for dissolved metals (indicates active corrosion)
- Symptoms: Early corrosion despite new installation
- Cause: Poor commissioning flush, flux residue, debris
* Thorough system flush with appropriate cleaners
* Verify all flux removed from soldered joints
- Symptoms: White deposits, reduced efficiency, leaks
- Cause: Incorrect pH, incompatible inhibitor, galvanic action
* Check for copper ions in system water
* Consider system filter with electrolytic protection
- Symptoms: Localized damage under sludge, scale
- Correct pipe sizing to minimize erosion
- Documentation of treatment for future reference
- Associated with bicarbonate, sulfate, chloride ions
- Permanent hardness remains regardless of heating
- Test incoming water hardness (test strips or titration)
- Compare open vs. closed system hardness
- Check flow restrictions at hot points
- Check for increasing delta T across heat exchanger
- Cause: Calcium carbonate precipitation on hot surfaces
* Adjust maximum temperature to reduce precipitation
* Install scale inhibitor or water softener
* Consider magnetic or electronic scale control
- Symptoms: Reduced flow, radiator cold spots
* Use scale inhibitors in system water
* Consider water softener for feed water
- Symptoms: Specific components affected (DHW plate, immersion)
- Cause: High temperature, high flow zones
* Regular maintenance schedule for critical components
2. Calculate scaling potential based on temperatures
- Fungi and algae (in lower temperature systems)
- Check for slime or biofilm in samples
- Look for colored slimes (red, black, green)
- Check for gas production in stagnant areas
- ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate) testing for biological activity
- Examine rubber and plastic components for deterioration
- Check for localized corrosion near deposits
- Look for gas pockets in high points
- Symptoms: Hydrogen sulfide odor, black deposits, pitting
- Symptoms: Blocked strainers, reduced flow, biofilm
- Symptoms: Localized pitting, unusual corrosion patterns
- Cause: Bacterial colonies creating corrosion cells
* Complete system clean with appropriate biocide
- Dip slide testing for bacterial counts
| Parameter | Ideal Range | Warning Signs | Critical Values |
| Inhibitor Level | Per manufacturer | <75% of recommended | <50% of recommended |
| System Type | Recommended Inhibitor | Dosage Rate | Special Considerations |
| Mixed metals with aluminum | Aluminum-compatible | 0.5-1% system volume | pH critical, typically 7.0-8.0 |
| Steel radiators with copper | Multi-metal inhibitor | 1% system volume | Higher dose for older systems |
| Underfloor with plastic pipe | Compatible anti-corrosion | 0.5% system volume | Check pipe manufacturer guidance |
| Steel commercial systems | Nitrite-based treatment | As specified | Regular testing essential |
| Systems with antifreeze | Compatible inhibitor | 1% + antifreeze % | Check for inhibitor in antifreeze |
| System Condition | Recommended Cleaning | Contact Time | Follow-up Treatment |
| New installation | Mild cleaner for flux/oils | 1-2 hours | Inhibitor addition |
| Light magnetite | Dispersant cleaner | 2-4 hours | Thorough flush, inhibitor |
| Heavy magnetite | Power flush with cleaner | 4-8 hours | Multiple rinses, inhibitor |
| Scale buildup | Acidic descaler (pH controlled) | Per manufacturer | Neutralization, inhibitor |
| Microbial contamination | Approved biocide | 1-4 hours | Flush, inhibitor with biocide |
| Issue | Treatment Option | Application | Maintenance Requirements |
| Hard water | Water softener | Whole system or feed | Salt replenishment, resin cleaning |
| Corrosion | Electrolytic scale reducer | System filtration | Annual anode inspection |
| Magnetite | Magnetic filter | Boiler protection | Regular cleaning (3-12 months) |
| General debris | Mechanical filter | System protection | Cartridge replacement as needed |
| Microbial control | UV treatment | Feed water | Lamp replacement, quartz cleaning |
| Combined issues | All-in-one filter system | Boiler protection | Multiple elements, scheduled service |
| Symptom | Possible Causes | Diagnostic Checks | Solutions |
| Black water | Magnetite suspension | Magnetic response, settling | Power flush, magnetic filter |
| Kettling noise | Scale on heat exchanger | Hardness test, temperature check | Descale, water treatment |
| Repeated pump failures | Debris, sludge | Filter inspection, water clarity | System clean, filtration |
| Pin-hole leaks | Microbial corrosion, erosion | Pattern analysis, bacterial test | Clean, biocide, repair |
| Radiator cold spots | Sludge accumulation | Bottom temperature, magnetic test | Power flush, inhibitor |
| System gas formation | Microbial activity, corrosion | Odor, gas type, pressure drops | Biocide, inhibitor, air removal |
